title: Ezekiel Chapter 17 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Ezekiel chapter 17 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Ezekiel Chapter 17 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Ezekiel Chapter 17.

questions.question: Who is commanded to put forth a riddle and speak a parable in Ezekiel 17?
questions.correctAnswer: Son of man
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:2 commands the 'Son of man' to put forth a riddle and speak a parable unto the house of Israel.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 17, what kind of bird is used in the parable?
questions.correctAnswer: Eagle
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:3 describes a great eagle with great wings and many feathers as part of the parable.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 17:4, where did the eagle carry the highest branch of the cedar?
questions.correctAnswer: To a city of merchants
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:4 states the eagle carried the highest branch into a land of traffick and set it in a city of merchants.

questions.question: What kind of plant did the eagle plant by great waters according to Ezekiel 17:5?
questions.correctAnswer: A willow tree
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:5 explains that the eagle planted seed in a fruitful field by great waters as a willow tree.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 17:7 mentions another great eagle with great wings and many feathers.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:7 clearly states there was another great eagle with great wings and many feathers.

questions.question: What did the vine do in relation to the second eagle in Ezekiel 17:7?
options: Bent her roots and shot branches toward him
questions.correctAnswer: Bent her roots and shot branches toward him
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:7 describes the vine bending her roots and shooting branches toward the second eagle.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 17:12, who came to Jerusalem and took the king and princes?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:12 states the king of Babylon came to Jerusalem and took the king and princes with him to Babylon.

questions.question: What did the king of Babylon take from the king's seed according to Ezekiel 17:13?
options: Made a covenant and took an oath
questions.correctAnswer: Made a covenant and took an oath
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:13 explains the king of Babylon made a covenant with the king's seed and took an oath from him.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 17:15 says the king rebelled by sending ambassadors to Egypt for horses and many people.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:15 states the king rebelled by sending ambassadors into Egypt to get horses and many people.

questions.question: Where will the king who broke the covenant die according to Ezekiel 17:16?
questions.correctAnswer: In Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:16 declares the king who broke the covenant will die in Babylon where he was made king.

questions.question: What will Pharaoh and his army fail to do for the king according to Ezekiel 17:17?
options: Make for him in the war by casting up mounts and building forts
questions.correctAnswer: Make for him in the war by casting up mounts and building forts
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:17 states Pharaoh and his army will not succeed in helping the king by building mounts or forts in war.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'Therefore thus saith the Lord GOD; As I live, surely mine oath that he hath ______, and my covenant that he hath broken, even it will I recompense upon his own head.'
questions.correctAnswer: despised
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:19 uses the word 'despised' to describe the oath that the king broke and for which he will be recompensed.

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 17:20, what will God spread upon the king who broke the covenant?
questions.correctAnswer: A net
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:20 states God will spread a net upon the king and take him in His snare.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 17:21 says all fugitives and bands of the king shall fall by the sword and be scattered to all winds.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:21 confirms that the king's fugitives and bands will fall by the sword and be scattered to all winds.

questions.question: Where will God plant the tender highest branch of the cedar according to Ezekiel 17:22-23?
options: On a high mountain and eminent in Israel
questions.correctAnswer: On a high mountain and eminent in Israel
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:22-23 declares God will plant the tender branch on a high mountain in the mountain of Israel.

medium.title: Ezekiel Chapter 17 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Ezekiel Chapter 17 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with trusting God after facing betrayal. Based on Ezekiel 17, what biblical truth would you share about faith and obedience?
options: Trusting in God's covenant leads to stability and blessing
Relying on human alliances guarantees success
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting in God's covenant leads to stability and blessing
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:14, 17:19, and 17:24 show that keeping God's covenant is vital for standing firm, while rebellion leads to downfall and judgment.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 teach us about humility and contentment in leadership and authority?
options: A kingdom should not lift itself up but stand by keeping God's covenant
Leaders must seek power by any means
Humility is unnecessary if one has military strength
Contentment comes from wealth and alliances
questions.correctAnswer: A kingdom should not lift itself up but stand by keeping God's covenant
questions.explanation: Verse 14 says the kingdom might be base and not lift itself up, but stand by keeping the covenant, teaching humility and dependence on God rather than pride.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to break a solemn promise for short-term gain. According to Ezekiel 17, what principle about integrity and consequences would you encourage them with?
options: Breaking a covenant leads to being caught and punished
Promises can be broken without consequence
Integrity is optional in difficult times
God overlooks broken oaths if intentions are good
questions.correctAnswer: Breaking a covenant leads to being caught and punished
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:18-20 explains that breaking a covenant and despising an oath results in God's judgment and being caught in His snare.

questions.question: Based on Ezekiel 17, what does the parable of the vine teach about spiritual growth and dependence?
options: True growth depends on being nourished by God's care
Spiritual growth occurs apart from God
Power is found in alliances, not roots
questions.correctAnswer: True growth depends on being nourished by God's care
questions.explanation: Verses 5-8 show the vine planted by great waters, bending roots and branches toward the one who waters it, symbolizing dependence on God's provision for growth.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 encourage perseverance through trials when facing opposition?
options: God will exalt the humble and cause the proud to wither
Trials are a sign of God's rejection
Victory depends on human strength alone
questions.correctAnswer: God will exalt the humble and cause the proud to wither
questions.explanation: Verse 24 declares God brings down the high tree, exalts the low tree, dries up the green, and makes the dry flourish, showing God’s sovereign care for perseverance.

questions.question: A believer is feeling discouraged because their efforts seem fruitless. Based on Ezekiel 17, what biblical truth about fruitfulness and God's timing would you share?
options: Being planted in good soil and receiving God's care leads to fruitfulness
Fruitfulness depends on immediate visible success
God's blessing is random and unpredictable
questions.correctAnswer: Being planted in good soil and receiving God's care leads to fruitfulness
questions.explanation: Verses 7-8 describe the vine planted in good soil by great waters to bring forth branches and bear fruit, teaching dependence on God’s nurturing for growth.

questions.question: What does Ezekiel 17 teach about the consequences of seeking help from worldly powers instead of trusting God?
options: Rebellion by seeking Egypt’s help leads to downfall and death in Babylon
Alliances with powerful nations guarantee safety
God rewards those who form political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: Rebellion by seeking Egypt’s help leads to downfall and death in Babylon
questions.explanation: Verses 15-16 explain that the king who breaks his covenant by seeking Egypt’s help will die where he was made king, in Babylon, showing consequences of misplaced trust.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 17 teaches that God’s promises are sure and He will bring justice to those who break their covenant with Him.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verses 19-21 affirm God will recompense those who despise His oath and break His covenant, showing His justice is sure and certain.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 illustrate the importance of spiritual roots and nourishment in Christian life?
options: The vine’s roots bending toward the water symbolize dependence on God for life
Spiritual roots are irrelevant if one has strong branches
Nourishment comes from human wisdom alone
Roots only matter for physical growth
questions.correctAnswer: The vine’s roots bending toward the water symbolize dependence on God for life
questions.explanation: Verse 6 and 7 show the vine’s roots bending toward the great eagle to receive water, emphasizing the necessity of spiritual nourishment from God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Ezekiel 17, God can exalt the lowly and cause the proud to fall, demonstrating His control over human affairs.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 24 clearly states that God has brought down the high tree, exalted the low tree, and made the dry tree flourish, showing His sovereign authority.

questions.question: A parent wants to teach their child about faithfulness. Based on Ezekiel 17, which example best illustrates the value of keeping promises to God?
options: The king who kept his covenant stood firm and prospered
The king who broke his oath escaped punishment
Promises to God are symbolic but not binding
questions.correctAnswer: The king who kept his covenant stood firm and prospered
questions.explanation: Verses 13-14 show that keeping the covenant causes the kingdom to stand, highlighting faithfulness as crucial for stability and blessing.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 encourage believers to respond when tempted to compromise their spiritual commitments for worldly gain?
options: They should remember God’s judgment on covenant breakers
Worldly alliances protect from all harm
questions.correctAnswer: They should remember God’s judgment on covenant breakers
questions.explanation: Verses 18-20 warn that breaking God’s covenant results in judgment and being caught in His snare, urging believers to remain faithful.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and consequences can be learned from the fate of the king who rebelled against Babylon in Ezekiel 17?
options: Despising an oath and breaking a covenant leads to death and defeat
God tolerates broken promises for political gain
questions.correctAnswer: Despising an oath and breaking a covenant leads to death and defeat
questions.explanation: Verses 16-17 explain the king who broke his covenant will die in Babylon despite military help, showing consequences of lacking integrity.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Ezekiel 17 teaches that God will take the highest branch of the cedar, crop off a tender one, and plant it upon an ________ and eminent mountain.
questions.correctAnswer: high
questions.explanation: Verse 22 states God will plant the tender twig upon a high mountain and eminent, symbolizing exaltation and blessing from God.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 guide believers in dealing with temptation to seek help apart from God?
options: Trusting human strength leads to failure; faithfulness to God brings deliverance
God supports all human alliances equally
Temptation to seek help is always rewarded
questions.correctAnswer: Trusting human strength leads to failure; faithfulness to God brings deliverance
questions.explanation: Verses 15-21 warn that seeking help from Egypt instead of God leads to downfall and scattering, emphasizing reliance on God's power.

hard.title: Ezekiel Chapter 17 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Ezekiel Chapter 17.

questions.question: In Ezekiel 17, what does the 'great eagle with great wings' symbolically represent in the riddle told to the house of Israel?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:3-4 describes a great eagle with great wings that took the highest branch of the cedar, which symbolizes the king of Babylon taking the king of Judah.

questions.question: What is the significance of the cedar tree in Ezekiel 17's riddle?
options: It represents the kingdom of Judah
It refers to the temple in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It represents the kingdom of Judah
questions.explanation: The cedar tree is a common biblical symbol of strength and royalty, here representing the kingdom of Judah from which the highest branch was taken (Ezekiel 17:3).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 17, what was planted from the seed of the land in a fruitful field by great waters?
questions.correctAnswer: A willow tree
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:5 states that the seed from the land was planted in a fruitful field by great waters and set as a willow tree, symbolizing the transplanted branch.

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Ezekiel 17 when describing the great eagle and the vine?
questions.correctAnswer: Allegory
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17 uses allegory to convey political and spiritual realities through symbolic figures like the eagle and the vine (Ezekiel 17:3-8).

questions.question: Which historical event is alluded to in Ezekiel 17:12-13 regarding the king of Babylon and Jerusalem?
options: The exile of King Jehoiachin to Babylon
questions.correctAnswer: The exile of King Jehoiachin to Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:12-13 references the king of Babylon taking the king of Jerusalem and princes captive, paralleling the exile of Jehoiachin.

questions.question: What is the consequence foretold for the king who breaks the covenant by seeking help from Egypt in Ezekiel 17?
options: He will gain victory over Babylon
He will be crowned king of Egypt
questions.correctAnswer: He will die in Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:16 prophesies that the king who breaks the covenant by allying with Egypt will die in Babylon, the place of his making king.

questions.question: Ezekiel 17 speaks of an 'east wind' that will cause the vine to wither. What does this east wind symbolically represent?
options: Destructive forces such as invasion or judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Destructive forces such as invasion or judgment
questions.explanation: The east wind in Ezekiel 17:10 symbolizes a harsh, destructive force causing the vine to wither, often representing judgment or invasion in biblical imagery.

questions.question: True or False: Ezekiel 17 describes a covenant between the king of Babylon and the king of Jerusalem that was faithfully kept.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:14-15 explains that the covenant was broken by the king of Jerusalem who rebelled and sought aid from Egypt.

questions.question: What does the 'tender one' taken from the top of the highest branch and planted on a high mountain in Ezekiel 17 symbolize?
questions.correctAnswer: A future Davidic ruler
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:22-23 describes God planting a tender sprig on a high mountain, symbolizing the restoration of the Davidic line and hope for Israel's future.

questions.question: How does the imagery of the vine and the eagle in Ezekiel 17 foreshadow New Testament themes?
options: It prefigures Christ as the true vine and judgment upon nations
It predicts the fall of Rome
It corresponds to the parable of the talents
questions.correctAnswer: It prefigures Christ as the true vine and judgment upon nations
questions.explanation: The vine imagery in Ezekiel 17 prefigures Jesus' teaching of the true vine (John 15) and the eagle symbolizes judgment, connecting Old Testament prophecy with New Testament fulfillment.

questions.question: What is the theological significance of God declaring 'I have brought down the high tree, have exalted the low tree' in Ezekiel 17:24?
options: God sovereignly reverses fortunes to fulfill His purposes
God supports the proud and strong
questions.correctAnswer: God sovereignly reverses fortunes to fulfill His purposes
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:24 emphasizes God's sovereignty in humbling the proud and lifting the humble, a theme consistent throughout Scripture.

questions.question: In the context of Ezekiel 17, what does the act of cropping off the top of young twigs and transplanting them represent historically?
options: The exile and removal of royal heirs to Babylon
The building of altars in foreign lands
The planting of vineyards in Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: The exile and removal of royal heirs to Babylon
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:4 uses the metaphor of cropping and transplanting to describe the exile of Judah's king and royal seed to Babylon.

questions.question: Which aspect of ancient Near Eastern political culture is reflected in the covenant and oath described in Ezekiel 17:13-14?
options: Vassalage agreements involving hostages and oaths
questions.correctAnswer: Vassalage agreements involving hostages and oaths
questions.explanation: The taking of the king's seed and oath in Ezekiel 17:13-14 reflects the common ancient practice of securing vassal loyalty by hostages and binding oaths.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 use typology to convey God's judgment and restoration plan for Israel?
options: By depicting the exile as the withering vine and the future king as the tender sprig
By recounting historical battles in detail
questions.correctAnswer: By depicting the exile as the withering vine and the future king as the tender sprig
questions.explanation: The chapter typologically contrasts the decline of Israel (withered vine) with future hope (tender sprig), illustrating judgment and restoration (Ezekiel 17:9-10, 22-23).

questions.question: What does the phrase 'all fowl of every wing shall dwell under it' in Ezekiel 17:23 symbolize in the context of biblical imagery?
options: The gathering of diverse peoples under God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The gathering of diverse peoples under God's kingdom
questions.explanation: Biblical imagery often uses birds dwelling under a tree to symbolize protection and inclusion, here indicating God's kingdom gathering all peoples (Ezekiel 17:23).

theological.title: Ezekiel Chapter 17 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Ezekiel Chapter 17 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What symbolic figure is introduced at the beginning of Ezekiel 17 to represent power and influence?
options: A great eagle with great wings
A lion with a mighty roar
questions.correctAnswer: A great eagle with great wings
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:3 introduces a great eagle with great wings as a symbol of power, consistent with other biblical uses of the eagle to represent a dominant kingdom or God's sovereign power (cf. Deuteronomy 28:49, Revelation 12:14, Isaiah 40:31).

questions.question: What does the highest branch of the cedar represent in the parable of Ezekiel 17?
questions.correctAnswer: The king of Jerusalem
questions.explanation: The highest branch of the cedar symbolizes the king of Jerusalem, taken by the eagle to a land of traffic, representing the exile (Ezekiel 17:3-4). This aligns with biblical imagery where the cedar often symbolizes Israel or its leaders (cf. Psalm 92:12, Jeremiah 17:8, Ezekiel 31:3).

questions.question: According to Ezekiel 17, what happens to the young twig taken from the cedar and planted in a fruitful field?
options: It grows into a spreading vine
It turns into a mighty oak
questions.correctAnswer: It grows into a spreading vine
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:6 describes the young twig growing into a spreading vine of low stature, symbolizing a diminished but growing kingdom, consistent with the theme of restoration and growth found in scriptures like Jeremiah 13:21 and Hosea 14:7.

questions.question: What is the significance of the second great eagle mentioned in Ezekiel 17?
options: It represents another political power to which the vine turns
It is a metaphor for Egypt's army
It denotes the city of Jerusalem
questions.correctAnswer: It represents another political power to which the vine turns
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:7 depicts the vine bending its roots and branches toward the second great eagle, indicating a political alliance or dependence, which symbolizes the rebellious action of seeking help from Egypt (cf. Ezekiel 17:15).

questions.question: What is the outcome predicted for the vine that turns to the second eagle for help?
options: It will wither and not prosper
It will become a mighty tree
questions.correctAnswer: It will wither and not prosper
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:9-10 warns that the vine will not prosper and will wither, highlighting the consequences of unfaithfulness and reliance on worldly powers, a theme echoed in Proverbs 11:3 and Jeremiah 17:5.

questions.question: What covenant did the king of Babylon make with the king of Jerusalem according to Ezekiel 17?
options: An oath to keep the kingdom low and dependent
A pact to share the land equally
A promise to protect Jerusalem from Egypt
An agreement to conquer Egypt together
questions.correctAnswer: An oath to keep the kingdom low and dependent
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:13-14 explains that the Babylonian king made a covenant and oath with the king of Jerusalem to keep the kingdom base and dependent, which reflects God's sovereign control over nations and judgments (cf. Psalm 75:6-7, Daniel 4:17, Isaiah 10:5).

questions.question: What sin did the king of Jerusalem commit that broke the covenant with Babylon?
options: He sent ambassadors to Egypt seeking horses and people
questions.correctAnswer: He sent ambassadors to Egypt seeking horses and people
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:15 reveals that the king rebelled by sending ambassadors to Egypt for military aid, breaking the covenant with Babylon, illustrating the folly of political alliances over faithfulness to God's sovereign plans (cf. Isaiah 30:1-2, Jeremiah 37:5).

questions.question: What is the predicted fate of the king of Jerusalem who broke the covenant with Babylon?
options: He will die in Babylon where he was made king
He will reign for many years
He will be restored to power
questions.correctAnswer: He will die in Babylon where he was made king
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:16 states that the king who despised the oath and broke the covenant will die in Babylon, reinforcing the certainty of divine judgment and the fulfillment of God's word (cf. 2 Kings 25:7, Jeremiah 39:7, Daniel 5:30).

questions.question: What does God promise to do to the rebellious king who broke his oath, according to Ezekiel 17?
options: Spread a net and catch him in a snare
Exalt him as a warning to others
questions.correctAnswer: Spread a net and catch him in a snare
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:20 describes God spreading a net to capture the king for his trespasses, demonstrating God's justice and sovereignty over human rebellion (cf. Psalm 91:3, Proverbs 1:31, Habakkuk 1:17).

questions.question: What will happen to the fugitives and bands of the rebellious king as prophesied in Ezekiel 17?
options: They will fall by the sword and be scattered
They will find refuge in Egypt
They will form a new kingdom
They will be taken captive to Assyria
questions.correctAnswer: They will fall by the sword and be scattered
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:21 prophesies that all fugitives and bands will fall by the sword and be scattered, reflecting the consequences of rebellion and fulfilled judgment seen throughout Scripture (cf. Jeremiah 24:10, 2 Chronicles 36:19, Ezekiel 12:15).

questions.question: In Ezekiel 17, what does God say He will do with the highest branch of the high cedar?
options: Plant it on a high mountain and make it a goodly cedar
Cut it down and scatter it
questions.correctAnswer: Plant it on a high mountain and make it a goodly cedar
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:22-23 promises God will take the highest branch and plant it on a high mountain in Israel, where it will flourish, symbolizing restoration and messianic hope (cf. Isaiah 2:2, Psalm 92:12, Jeremiah 23:5).

questions.question: What is signified by the birds dwelling under the branches of the restored cedar in Ezekiel 17?
options: Protection and refuge under God's kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: Protection and refuge under God's kingdom
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:23 speaks of birds dwelling in the shadow of the cedar's branches, symbolizing the safety and peace found under God's reign, paralleling biblical imagery in Psalm 91:4 and Revelation 22:1-2.

questions.question: What theological truth does Ezekiel 17:24 emphasize about God's sovereignty?
options: God brings down the high tree and exalts the low tree
God is limited by human actions
God only judges Israel and not other nations
God's plans can be thwarted by political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: God brings down the high tree and exalts the low tree
questions.explanation: Ezekiel 17:24 declares God's sovereign power to humble the proud and exalt the humble, a fundamental biblical doctrine consistent with 1 Samuel 2:7, Luke 1:52, and James 4:6.

questions.question: How does Ezekiel 17 illustrate the consequences of human rebellion against God's covenant?
options: Through the parable of the vine that withers when turning from its source
Through a vision of fiery judgment only
By promising unconditional success despite rebellion
questions.correctAnswer: Through the parable of the vine that withers when turning from its source
questions.explanation: The parable in Ezekiel 17:6-10 depicts the vine withering due to turning from its covenantal source, teaching that rebellion leads to ruin, paralleling Proverbs 3:5-6 and John 15:4-6.

questions.question: What messianic hope can be derived from the imagery of the tender twig planted on the high mountain in Ezekiel 17?
options: It foreshadows the coming righteous king from David's line
It predicts the destruction of Israel forever
It represents an earthly king only
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows the coming righteous king from David's line
questions.explanation: The tender twig in Ezekiel 17:22-24 symbolizes a future king who will reign righteously, consistent with messianic prophecies in Isaiah 11:1, Jeremiah 23:5, and Zechariah 3:8, pointing toward Christ.
